awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Human-Aware Platform for Socially Collaborative Personal Artificial Intelligence (AI) Assistants
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is enabling Artificial Intelligence (AI) assistants to become proactive, empowering them to provide better service to users. Currently, commercial AI assistants respond to user requests reactively. The technologies developed in this project would provide AI assistants with the situational awareness to understand users’ lives and predict their needs.  The technology will also enable social intelligence to take the initiative to support users in appropriate ways. This SBIR Phase I project will apply these technologies to a consumer product for assisting users with time management and meeting goals while establishing and strengthening healthy, desirable habits in their daily lives. Proactive personal AI assistants have the potential to improve productivity, convenience, and quality of life for every person, as well as to promote aging in place with greater independence and wellness. Fundamental scientific advancements will also enable a new generation of potential applications for AI assistants across sectors, fueling economic growth and creating jobs. 

This project addresses two central technical challenges for enabling proactive AI assistants: contextual awareness of users and agent-initiated interaction. Contextual awareness includes the AI agent’s real-time understanding of current user state and activity, as well as a long-term understanding of past user habits. The project proposes to develop hybrid computational models combining machine learning of multimodal user observations from visual, acoustic, and geolocation data with probabilistic graphical models that perform long-term inference and prediction over historical user observations. A virtually-embodied AI agent will leverage these contextual awareness representations to conduct real-time, face-to-face collaborations with users. The project proposes to research and develop a dynamic scheduling approach to proactively enable the agent to communicate with users. These models will be integrated within a broader system that assists users with time management. This system will implement an end-to-end architecture for protecting user privacy while handling their data. The technical solution will be validated based on quantitative metrics related to utility and user acceptance by deploying the prototype in end users’ homes over a multi-week period and conducting surveys about their subjective experience of the proactive AI assistants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project resulted in the development of a computational architecture for a human-aware, socially collaborative A.I. agent capable of taking initiative to assist users proactively. Proactive behavior stands in contrast with previous generations of A.I. voice assistants, which only react to user input. The A.I. agent developed in this project features a virtual character embodiment that engages users socially across multiple interaction surfaces, including an app on the user's personal smartphone and an always-on app running on one or more tablets situated in the user's home. 

The technical aims of the project focused largely on context-aware user modeling and proactive interaction control. A real-time state estimation pipeline for situated interaction was demonstrated to be feasible using an entirely on-device processing pipeline that could run on off-the-shelf, commercially available tablet hardware. For long-term user state estimation and prediction, a novel multimodal model was developed and employed in the cloud. To achieve proactive interaction, a formalism for interaction control was developed to enable autonomous agent behavior and decision-making to be distributed and synchronized across cloud servers and client devices. 

These methods were deployed in the context of an end-to-end software system prototype enabling an A.I. virtual character to assist users with time management. A personal schedule management application was implemented using the integrated A.I. platform, in which an end user could access the app through their personal smartphone and an always-on, centrally located in-home tablet. The A.I. agent could take initiative to communicate with the user about their schedule throughout the day through face-to-face interaction at the tablet when user presence was detected, or through notification messages on the user's smartphone. 

A set of approaches and practices was also developed surrounding the privacy and security of personal user data. This comprehensive framework covered authentication, encryption, on-device processing, interaction design for informed consent, and software development practices. 

A user study was conducted using the prototype system with the aim of evaluating user acceptance and commercial viability. Study participants interacted with the system in their homes for a minimum of one week and were surveyed about their attitudes towards the A.I. agent. The integrated system was able to achieve a level of initiative that was perceived by users as being proactive and aware of their presence. User attitudes relating to the privacy approaches taken were characterized on a per-modality basis. Overall, participants expressed interest in adopting and willingness to pay for a proactive personal A.I. agent with additional features within and extending beyond the calendar assistance domain. Concrete next steps were identified for technical system improvement, privacy design, and application feature development to make further progress towards commercialization. 

The broader impact of this project is to enable A.I. assistants to become proactive, rather than only reacting to user-initiated requests. Proactive agent behavior depends on situational understanding of user context as well as autonomous decision-making and action execution. Personal A.I. assistants with these capabilities can help people to stay on top of their schedules, meet their goals, strengthen desirable habits, and enact positive behavior change. The delivery of such technologies to the market through a consumer product has the potential to improve productivity, convenience, and quality of daily life for a broad population. 


Last Modified: 07/10/2024
Modified by: Crystal Chao
